column3: In order to cover up spoiled meat, the factory would do the bare minimum. In the second paragraph, it says "To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor—a process known to the workers as 'giving them thirty percent.'" These factories would put spoiled meat products in with fresh products to level it out and help them go unnoticed. These factories would also take out parts of the ham to resell it at top value. Also in the second paragraph, it says "later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron. After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade—there was only Number One Grade." By making meats boneless these companies and factories would be able to avoid the bad quality labels and would be able to get away with a possibly dangerous health risk.  These factories would grind up meats and animal products that had gone bad in order to support the high demand and save money, despite the potential harm that this process has on customers. This can be supported by a sentence in the third paragraph that says "Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions- a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference."
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  In order to disguise spoiled meat products, factories would resort to minimal coverage. A second and stronger pickle was used to cover rotten meat. These factories would blend spoiled meat with fresh meat to cover the bad smell. Some clever engineers discovered a method, extracting the bone from the meat, inserting it into holes in the flesh, and welding it back in. This method eradicated the number system of the best, second, and third grades of meat. The factories exploited this loophole by grinding up the spoiled meat and animal products to increase demand while discarding the unpleasant odor and label.

column3: The Egyptian government is in some ways like how it is today. the pharaohs being the presidents, the nobles/priests being the vice presidents (paragraph 6), the scribes/viziers being the Speaker of the House of Representatives, and the farmers/slaves being citizens/prisoners (paragraph 5). The soldiers were treated with the same respect they are today.  People's social class was determined by their job. Most craftsmen and artisans were considered the middle class, but the farmers/slaves were seen as the lower class (paragraph 11). In Egyptian fashion, the social classes were put into a pyramid-shaped structure. (upper class, middle class, lower class.) The lower class would "build the pyramids" for the upper class. The upper class was seen as wealthy, whilst the middle class was seen as the people with jobs like craftsmen and artisans.
column4: The Egyptian government operates similarly to its current form, with the Pharaohs serving as the head of state, noble figures holding positions similar to the vice presidency, scribes and viziers serving in leadership roles within the government, and farmers and slaves considered citizens with basic rights. Soldiers were treated with respect mirroring modern-day values. Social mobility in ancient Egypt was closely tied to occupation, with craftsmen and artisans belonging to the middle class, while farmers and slaves were placed in the lower class. The social hierarchy was visualized through a pyramid, with the lower class building structures for the upper class, while the upper class was perceived as affluent

column3: Aristotle first states that a tragedy should "... be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan," which means that the plot should be interesting and detailed (paragraph two). Then he goes on to state that the events of the tragedy should excite readers and let them feel "pity" and "fear" which draw the reader in and make them more interested (paragraph two). Lastly, the main character must not be an evil person, but he must also not be a perfect citizen. The main character should have "...some error of judgement or frailty," but he should not be evil (paragraph two). Overall, the three aspects that were mentioned were that the plot should be elaborate, the plot should cause excitement and intererest, and the main hero should be a neither evil nor perfect.
column4: Aristotle believed that a tragedy should be captivating, engaging, and emotionally resonant. His writing emphasized that the plot should be intricate and well-developed, the events should evoke both pity and fear in the reader, and the protagonist should possess a flaw or weakness that adds depth and intrigue to the narrative. Additionally, Aristotle stressed that the tragic hero should not be a villain or an idealized citizen, but rather someone with a tragic flaw that sets them apart from society.

column3: At the very top were the gods, who were believed to be able to create life, bring famine, bring Death, cause floodings, and etc. Up next were pharoahs, who were believed to be the gods in their human form. They were tasked with ruling Egypt, protecting Egypt, and they had an assisstant; the vivizer. The viviser's were to help the Pharoahs make sure that every member of Egypt payed their taxes. Along with the vivizer's, there were scribes, whom which could read and write. They also kept government records. Right below them we have the Nobles and Priests, whom which Priests were tasked with pleasing the gods. Nobles were the only class that could hold government posts. Nobles enjoyed great status and grew wealthy from donations to the gods of Egypt. Up next we have Soldiers.  Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. They also supervised slaves, peasants, and farmers during times of piece. Just below them were Egyptians with jobs. These egyptians sold many useful things. Finally, at the bottom of the Egyptian society are the slaves, peasants, and farmers. Slaves were the fate of whom were captured in war, and slaves toiled at the descretion of the pharoah or nobles. Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in gooc order,  worked in stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. Egyptian society was shaped like a pyramid, with the classes being more powerful as you go up and less powerful when you go futher down.
column4: At the summit were the gods, regarded as creators, destroyers, and nurturers, responsible for bringing life, famine, death, floods, and performing other miracles. Below the gods were the pharaohs, transformed humans responsible for ruling Egypt, protecting it, and ensuring the payment of taxes. The vivizer played a vital role in maintaining the stability of the pharaohs, assisting them to make sure every citizen paid their taxes. Alongside the vivizer were scribes, skilled professionals tasked with reading and writing. They also maintained government records. Just below the scribes were the nobles and priests, the elite ruling class responsible for mediating between the gods and the people. Nobles enjoyed significant status and wealth from offerings and donations, with most of the high-ranking positions reserved for them. The army, composed primarily of soldiers, played a significant role in maintaining order and carrying out various tasks, including military campaigns and suppressing uprisings. Additionally, they supervised and managed the lives of slaves, farmers, and laborers during times of peace and war. Finally, at the base of the pyramid-like society were the slaves, peasants, and farmers. Slavery represented their fate in war and the involuntary servitude of those deemed worthy by the ph

column4: At the base of the social hierarchy were farmers and slaves. Farmers were responsible for tending the fields and raising animals, while also contributing 60% of their yearly harvest to taxes. They were divided into three classes: the middle class, which included physicians and crafts men, who produced and sold the goods that were purchased by the merchants; the upper class, made up of nobles and priests, who held the highest political and economic power and profited from those positions; and the pharohs, the leaders of the government, who were considered divine figures in human form. However, the pharohs needed assistance, and they had a system of supervisors called vizier who monitored the slaves and could read and write, a rare skill in ancient Egypt.

column4: The ruling system of ancient Egypt was hierarchical, with the pharaoh at the top, followed by nobles and priests. The pharaoh was considered a god and a king, responsible for overseeing the nation. Nobles held significant political and economic power, fulfilling legal and administrative tasks. Priests were entrusted with communicating with the gods, ensuring their favor. The middle class was composed of Crafts people, scribes, farmers, servants, and slaves. They performed essential labor that supported the pharaoh and maintained order in society.

column3: As Aristotle states, there are many key elements to a tragedy. Aristotle claims that without these key elements, the work can not be considered a tragedy. These elements shape how the plot should look, and what the characters should act like. The first of these elements is a complex plan that arouses both pity and fear. Another key element that relates to this, is how the story should not be morally satisfying. This would make the story irregular and make it even more "sad" for a reader. Characters also need to be specific to produce a good tragedy, the main character must start in a high, well regarded position and take a massive fall into a more depressing state.
column4: Aristotle believed that a tragedy must have specific elements to be considered a tragedy. These elements include a complex plot that creates both pity and fear, a morally unsatisfying conclusion that makes a work difficult to read, and specific characters with unique traits. Additionally, the main character must have a high standing and start their journey in a positive position before experiencing a significant decline, ending in a more tragic state.

column4: The Egyptian government provided a framework for the people's hierarchy. The pharaoh was believed to be a god determined to ensure the prosperity of the nation. Nobles and Priests held significant positions, as they were responsible for maintaining a favorable climate for the pharaoh. Middle-class individuals, including soldiers and craftsmen, also played a role in the government, serving in a variety of capacities. Peasants and slaves were mostly exempt from taxation, but they were responsible for contributing to the construction and maintenance of temple structures, such as pyramids and palaces. Skilled artisans, such as physicians and craftspeople, formed an important segment of society. Farmers and slaves were among the lowest rungs of the social ladder and were taxed heavily.

column3: the first would be that the main character of the play is neither good nor bad and the story of what happens to them goes from good to bad.  The second is that it focuses on a single issue, not several at one time. And finally, the issue should come from a fault of the character that is going through the issue.
column4: The main character of the play is neither virtuous nor villainous, and the story follows a journey from virtue to villainy.  The focus is on a single major issue, with the source of the issue stemming from the character's own flaws.

column3: Aristotle believed that the ideal tragedy should consist of the creation of pity and fear, a complex plan, and character that is subject to "error of judgement." The creation of pity and fear in the viewers is critical for a play because it is the "distinctive mark of tragic imitation." If it instead brings prosperity to adversity, the play doesn't invoke pity or fear and the result is just shock to the viewer, which is not the intention. A complex plot is also involved in an idealogical tragedy. Tragedies aim to be "single in tissue, rather than double as maintain." The plot should also not follow a storyline that goes from bad to good, but actually good to bad.  Lastly, character is another important aspect. Character is usually one that is considered to be a person who is good, but suffers misfortune and even their downfall due to their own judgement, making them very relatable. Usually they are also famous and prosperous, as seen with Oedipus and Thyestes. Therefore, pity and fear, complex plots, and character are all crucial to an idealogical tragedy.
column4: Aristotle believed that a tragedy should consist of elements that evoke a sense of pity and fear and use a complex plot design. It is important to create a sense of drama and tension in the play through the use of these elements. A tragedy should have a single, consistent plot structure that follows a natural progression and should not have a storyline that progresses from bad to good. Character is also a vital element as it helps to create a sense of connection between the audience and the characters.

column3: According to Aristotle, 3 elements of an ideal tragedy include being complex, being emotional, and having a character go from good to bad fortune. First, Aristotle explains that "a perfect tragedy should be arranged not on the simple but on the complex plan". (Aristotle 2). Aristotle continues by suggesting that the tragedy should "imitate actions which excite pity and fear" and calls this the "distinctive mark of tragic imitation" (Aristotle 2). This desire for readers to feel pitiful and fearful leads to Aristotle's second element of an ideal tragedy; for it to be emotional. Aristotle claims that an emotional piece "is proper rather to Comedy," suggesting that all tragedies should end with the reader feeling sorrow. (Aristotle 4). Lastly, the author states that the ideal tragedy "should be not from bad to good, but, reversely, from good to bad" (Aristotle 3). Aristotle believes that the ideal tragedy should include "that of a man who is not eminently good and just, yet whose misfortune is brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgment or frailty" (Aristotle 3).
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  According to Aristotle, a tragic play should be complex, evoke emotional responses in the audience, and have a protagonist who undergoes a journey from good to bad fortune. First, Aristotle suggests composing a tragedy on a complex structure rather than a simple one. Secondly, he emphasizes that a tragedy should use actions that evoke a sense of pity and fear in the audience, which is the "distinctive mark of tragic imitation". Thirdly, Aristotle highlights the importance of an emotional element in a tragedy, claiming that a tragic play should end with the audience feeling sorrow and empathy for the protagonist. Lastly, Aristotle argues that a tragedy should follow the pattern of a protagonist who starts as inherently good or just but is ultimately overcome by misfortune due to a mistake or weakness.

column3: In the exerpt from the text "The Jungle," Upton Sinclair exposes the unsanitary conditions found in meatpacking factories during the early 20th century in America. To cover up these atrocities, meatpackers used various techniques. Among these are pumping spoiling hams with a "much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor . . . ." They also took whole hams that had gone completely bad and "Cut [them] up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed [them] with half a ton of other meat, [so that] no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference." In other cases, when there was "old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white -- it would be dosed with borax and glycerin, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over . . . ." These are just some of the many things done to hide the horrible meat produced from the factories.
column4: In the text "The Jungle," Upton Sinclair exposes the appalling conditions found in meatpacking factories during the early 20th century in America. To conceal these atrocities, meatpackers employed various techniques, including adding spoiled hams to sausages, cutting up old sausage that was moldy and white, and mixing old sausage with new meat. These methods allowed meatpackers to preserve the unsanitary conditions, preserving their profits and reputations.

column3: A change of fortune from good to poor, a fall by decision, and a virtuous character are three elements of an ideal tragedy, as defined by Aristotle. Aristotle emphasizes the idea that there must be an unforeseen misfortune in a great disaster, from good to poor, not bad to good. The audience is moved by this abrupt change of fortune as it creates a sense of pity and concern for the characters. He also assumed that the character would endure a fall due to their own error of judgement in an ideal tragedy. As it should be "brought about not by vice or depravity, but by some error of judgement or frailty." By this approach, the text represented it as being able to alter the audience's perception of the personality and behavior of the character. Aristotle also believes that the main character should have "highly renowned and prosperous" qualities and characteristics of virtue. This meant that the character should be very prominent and able to honour much admiration and status.
column4: Sure, here is the revised passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  "A tragic drama is characterized by a dramatic shift in fortunes from prosperity to poverty, a decision-related downfall, and a virtuous character who experiences a tragic fall due to their own fault. This sudden shift from good fortune to hardship creates a sense of pity and concern for the characters, as it amplifies their sufferings and underscores the consequences of bad decisions. Additionally, the text assumes that the character would endure a fall due to their own error, emphasizing the importance of a tragic hero's moral virtue."

The structure of the ancient Egyptian system was built like a pyramid. There are three classes. The Upper class, the Middle class, and the Lower class. The Upper class involves all the cheifs, and powerful nobles and preists They each had a specific job. According to the text, it states 
 "Only nobles could hold government posts; in these positions they profited from tributes paid to the pharaoh. Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods." The Middle class involves all the skilled workers such as physicians and craftsmen/women. According to the text, it says " Craftsmen made and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful things. "  And finally, the lowest class makes up the slaves and farmers. According to the text, it states, "Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war. In addition to being forced to work on building projects, slaves toiled at the discretion of the pharaoh or nobles." Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments.Farmers tended the fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries, and built the royal monuments. The Middle class was composed of skilled workers in various fields such as medicine and craftsmanship. Craftsmen produced and sold jewelry, pottery, papyrus products, tools, and other useful items, enriching the society. The lower class consisted of slaves and farmers, who endured harsh conditions and played crucial roles in maintaining the economy of the ancient civilization.

column4: Sure, here is a rewritten version of the passage, with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  "In this factory, many techniques were used to cover up the smell of spoiled meat. Some workers rubbed chemicals directly on the meat, while others added it to expired meat or used coloring to conceal the smell. A machine was used to pump a solution of borax and glycerin directly into the meat while it was being smoked. This process preserved the meat and gave it a brown color. The smell of spoiled meat was completely eliminated this way.  The factory also preserved meat in a way that produced fake "smoked" meat. Workers soaked the meat in a borax and glycerin solution, which they then added a gelatin to give it a brown color. This process fooled consumers into thinking that the meat was actually smoked.  The workers employed a variety of techniques to preserve spoiled meat, ensuring that it could be sold and consumed safely and legally."

column3: Three elements of an ideal tragedy as described by Aristotle is one, having  a plot where a man that is not good or evil have his life face some kind of misfortune because of a mistake or problem they did. This is so the audience can have feelings of pity and fear, and also for the audience to relate to. Another is that the plot must be single in its issue instead of double, and the change of fortune should should be not from bad to good, but reversed.  One final element is that the play should end unhappily.
column4: A tragedy should have a single plot, with a single main conflict that creates a sense of tragedy. The play should focus on the feelings of pity and fear generated by the protagonist's misfortune. It should be single in structure, with a reversal of fortunes from bad to good. The play should conclude with a sense of finality and hopelessness.

column3: The Egyptian government and social class structure was similar to the structure of a pyramid. At the top were the gods and pharaohs becuase they held the most power. People believed pharaohs were gods in human form. Next, were the nobles and priests. People of this rank had duties to fufill such as pleasing the pharaoh and gods. According to the article,  "All Egyptians-from pharaohs to farmers-gave gifts to the gods." Occupying the middle class were skilled workers like craftspeople,  and physicians, as well as artisians, traders, merchants and storekeepers. These people sold goods and other products to the public. Finally, at the lowest level on the social pyramid, were slaves and farmers. As the article states, "Slavery became the fate of those captured as prisoners of war." Slaves were forced to work on building projects and other difficult tasks that only people on the lowest level of the social class pyramid would do. The article says "Farmers tended fields, raised animals, kept canals and reservoirs in good order, worked in the stone quarries and built the royal monuments." Farmers also paid taxes that could equal as much as 60% of their yearly harvest. The article also explains how social mobility was possible. Men could learn to become scribes and work their way up the social pyramid. However, their families would have to pay for a special school for them to do so. So, to conclude, ancient Egypt was made up of a pyramid of social classes and government that worked together to help Egypt function.
column4: The ancient Egyptian social structure mirrored the hierarchy of a pyramid. The ruling class, comprising the gods and pharaohs, held immense power and significant influence. Nobles and priests played vital roles in upholding the rules and maintaining social order. The class below them comprised skilled workers, artisans, traders, and storekeepers who engaged in commerce. The lowest tier was populated by slaves and farmers, forced to fulfill tasks that were largely beyond their capabilities. Despite these hierarchies, social mobility was achievable, as individuals could rise to positions of greater influence through special education and opportunities offered by the ruling elite.

column3: An ideal tragedy should make the reader or audience feel pity and fear for a character that is most relatable to the reader. The character must face misfortune due to bad habits or due to corruption over his/her morals all of which is brought about by a misunderstanding or "error of judgment". Finally, the point in which the story turns it must go from good to bad and not the other way around because it generates a sense of pity for the character which is the goal.
column4: An ideal tragedy should evoke a sense of pity and fear within the reader through relatable character facing misfortune due to poor choices and moral compromises. The character’s journey should take a turn from good to bad rather than the opposite because it creates a stronger emotional impact on the reader.

column3: There are at least three elements, as described by Aristotle, that should define an ideal tragedy. One element that makes up a perfect tragedy is actions that instill pity and fear from the audience. For example, what should be avoided is "spectacle of a virtuous man brought from prosperity to adversity: for this moves neither pity nor fear; it merely shocks us (Aristotle 2). " Another element to creating an ideal tragedy is the change of fortune. The change of fortune must always be from good to bad to properly create the emotions that tragedy should expel from the audience.  Finally, the change of fortune should be caused by a great error or frailty. This way the audience can relate to the characters experiencing the tragedy and feel pity for the characters, or feel fear that this tragedy could happen to them.
column4: Sure, here is the rewritten passage with a similar number of words and writing ability level:  "There are at least three elements that contribute to the beauty of a tragedy. Firstly, a tragedy should evoke a sense of pity and fear in the audience. Such an emotional response is what allows the audience to connect with the characters, feel their pain and sorrow, and understand the tragic themes of the play. Secondly, the protagonist's journey should change over the course of the play. The transformation must be from positive to negative to create an impactful and emotional experience for the audience. Lastly, the tragic fate should be caused by a significant error or setback that gives the audience a

column3: The structure of the Egyptian system is divided into classes.  These classes are based on your wealth.  Pharaohs were seen as gods in human form and were highly respected so they were at the top and were responsible for providing protection for everyone.  The text says, "Because the people of Egypt believed that their pharaohs were gods, they entrusted their rulers with many responsibilities. Protection was at the top of the list."(#3)  Under pharaohs were nobles and priests and they were responsible for pleasing the pharaohs.  In the text it states, "Priests were responsible for pleasing the gods."(#6) Below them are soldiers.   These soldiers fought in times of war and when there was peace, they would supervise everyone, including farmers, that take part in building pyramids.  The text states, "Soldiers fought in wars or quelled domestic uprisings. During long periods of peace, soldiers also supervised the peasants, farmers, and slaves who were involved in building such structures as pyramids and palaces."(#8) Farmers and slaves were at the bottom tier.  Farmers were meant to take care of fields, raise animals, and pay taxes.  Slaves were forced to work on building projects.  Evidence that shows this in the text is, "Each farmer paid taxes in the form of grains, which were stored in the pharaoh’s warehouses. This grain was used to feed the people in the event of a famine."
column4: ## Reworded Passage  Sure, here is the rewritten passage:  The Egyptian system was divided into different classes based on social standing. Pharaohs were considered gods and were revered, holding supreme authority and responsibility for protecting the populace. Nobles and priests occupied positions of influence and were responsible for maintaining harmony and facilitating the pharaoh's desires. Soldiers played a vital role, safeguarding the people during warfare and peacetime by overseeing agriculture and construction projects. Farmers and slaves, the lowest tier of society, were responsible for the basic needs of the population, contributing to the construction of monuments like pyramids and palaces.

column4: The Ancient Egyptian Government consisted of a hierarchy where pharaohs, nobles, priests, soldiers, farmers, and slaves played distinct roles in maintaining societal stability and order. The pharaohs served as the pinnacle of this hierarchical system, holding significant authority and standing as the symbolic leaders of the state. The people of this society relied on pharaohs as gods in human form, recognizing their power and guidance through communication channels.

column3: According to Aristotle, an ideal tragedy should be developed a certain way. He mentions that the play should be complex and full of different "characters" and plots, instead of being simple and straight-forward. The tragedy shoud evoke a sense of pity as well as fear onto the audience over a character who does not move from prosperity to adversity (it is just shocking, not pitiful or fearful) or a character that does not face misfortune when they do not deserve it. Additonally, the swap of fortune should be from good to bad rather than bad to good, resulting in an unhappy ending. This, according to Aristotle, hightens the dramatic reaction to the tragedy. Lastly, Aristotle claims the perfect tragedy should be proper instead of comedic, should have conflict such as relationship changes and characters who are slain, and it should have plot in which is "double-threaded". In simpler terms, Aristotle believes the ideal tragedy is complex, has a change in plot from good to bad, and should make the audience feel pity and fear towards the actions against the main character.
column4: Sure. Here is the rewritten passage:  "According to Aristotle, a tragic play should exhibit complexity and diversity in its characters and plot—avoid simplicity and monotony. It should evoke a sense of sadness, both through the protagonist's journey of hardship and the devastating effects of their misfortune. Additionally, the character's fate should fluctuate from good to bad to reflect an unhappy ending. Finally, Aristotle believed that a tragic play should be serious and not comical, should contain a conflict that develops the relationships between characters, and should have a complex plot with a double storyline."
